importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication, indicating the most recent update on China's export controls on rare-earth metals.
The date when the new export restrictions on rare-earth metals and refining equipment will officially come into effect.
The date of the expected Trump-Xi meeting during the APEC summit in South Korea, which follows the announcement of China's export controls and is a key context for the strategic timing of the policy.

The window leading up to the Trump-Xi meeting at the APEC summit, during which China's action is interpreted as a strategic signaling move.

keyTakeAways: China has tightened export controls on 12 of the 17 rare-earth metals, including five new additions: holmium, erbium, thulium, europium, and ytterbium, bringing the total to 12 of the 17 metals (15 lanthanides plus scandium and yttrium).
The restrictions include export controls on specialized technological equipment used to refine rare-earth metals, effective from December 1, 2025.
Foreign companies must obtain special approvals from Beijing to export rare-earth magnets and semiconductor materials containing at least 0.1% heavy rare-earth metals.
China cites national security and threats from foreign organizations transferring or processing Chinese rare-earth materials for military use as justification for the controls.
The US is the largest importer of Chinese rare-earth products, having imported $22.8 million in 2023, with 70% of its rare-earth imports coming from China between 2020 and 2023.
Rare-earth metals are critical to key US defence systems such as F-35 fighter jets, Virginia-class submarines, Tomahawk missiles, and AI semiconductors.
The move is seen as a strategic signal ahead of the Trump-Xi meeting at APEC, enhancing China’s leverage in trade negotiations.
The restrictions may deepen existing vulnerabilities in US defence and technology supply chains, widening the capability gap between the US and China.
China emphasizes willingness to engage in dialogue to promote compliant trade and global supply chain stability.
Exemptions exist for emergency medical needs, public health emergencies, and disaster relief efforts.

summaryOfNewsArticle: China has tightened its export controls on 12 of the 17 rare-earth metals, adding five new ones — holmium, erbium, thulium, europium, and ytterbium — to a previous list of seven. The restrictions, announced by the Ministry of Commerce and effective from December 1, 2025, target both the metals and the specialized equipment used to refine them. Foreign companies must obtain special approvals detailing the intended use of products containing rare-earth metals, especially those with at least 0.1% heavy rare-earth content. China justifies the move on grounds of national security, citing unauthorized transfers of controlled materials to military or sensitive applications. The announcement comes just weeks before a high-stakes meeting between US President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping during the APEC summit in South Korea, positioning the controls as a strategic signal to strengthen China’s leverage in ongoing trade negotiations. As the US is the largest importer of Chinese rare-earth products and relies on them for critical defence systems and consumer technology, the restrictions are seen as a major threat to US industrial and military capabilities. Analysts, including from CSIS and the University of Montana, interpret the move as part of 'pre-meeting choreography' to pressure US policymakers, while China emphasizes openness to dialogue on export controls and supply chain stability.
title: China tightens export controls on rare-earth metals: Why this matters
